utterances: That's right.
I mean, basically, each object is resonated, so you got these fields that are going in and out.

And ordinarily, if you weren't in the strong-coupling regime, because the intersection of the field of one object that goes through to the other, which determines, sort of, the interaction strength is so small, you wouldn't get efficient power transfer.
But if we get the one object to excite the other in just the right way by operating this strong-coupling regime, then it can actually get efficient power transfer.
Yeah.
Aury(ph) in Louisville.
Hi, Aury.
Hi.
I'm wondering if this - if this would be harmless to wildlife; if this could potentially be used to power, say, electric cars or something like that.
And I'll take my answer off the air.
I think we should.
It's an interesting - two ideas.
First, the wildlife question, where we're talking about the biological effects, you're not familiar with yet.
But secondly, let's say you have electric cars.
And as standing at a stoplight, maybe there's a coupling device that gives them a little charge.
Would that work?
It's possible, you know.
Certainly.
But that's further out in the future.
We can do a few hundreds of watts with what we currently have.
And, you know, it could be extended.
But to power a car, you'd need higher levels of power and also, I mean, there's more - there would be a lot of change in infrastructure involved, right?
You'd have to turn up all these roads.
So, perhaps, one day in the future.
But right now, we're focusing on other things.
Now, your research is funded in part by MIT's Institute for Soldier Nanotechnologies, which is funded by the U.S.
Army, correct?
Does that mean that soldiers are going to be using this method first, or the technology that you're working on first, do you think?
Well, it's possible.
I mean, I'm sure that the Army will find some application for this.
It's funded by the Institute for Soldier Nanotechnologies because one of the professors in our group, John Joannopoulos, became director of the ISN one year ago.
And so, part of his grant was used to fund this project.
Does this also mean that you're using nanotechnology in your devices?
Well, not actually.
I mean, we have some ideas along those lines, but not right now.
I mean, that would make the device a lot more complicated and expensive.
Mm-hmm.
All right.
Tell us about the trail you're on.
What is your next step and where do you eventually want to take this?
Well, right now, we're working on improving the efficiency and the distances, and of course, reducing the size of the device coils so it can fit inside portable devices, for example.
And since I'm...
How big is the coil now?
Well, actually they're both the same size because, you know, just for simplicity.
It was, just a lab experiment - let's say 12 inches in radius.
Right.
So, you know, they're kind of big and - but, you know, we can make, at least one them smaller so it can fit inside the devices.
And we're also, of course, looking at safety regulations because, of course, lots of people are contacting us, you know, asking about safety implications.
So, of course, we need to analyze that very carefully.
Mm-hmm.
And so, you want to shrink down the size of the coils, both receiver and transmitter, so that they could sit on a desk next to each other?
Yes, something along those lines.
Or, were they just have to be in the same room together because, you know, if you have to put it next to a device, might as well plug it in.
Yeah, it's very true.
No. I mean, yes.
As you say, we'd like it to be very, well, you know, we'd like to be as unobtrusive as possible.
And how soon do you think you'll have something for us all to take home with us?
Well, hopefully, within a couple of years, if there are no - we don't run into any major obstacles.
There'll be some sort of application of this, maybe not necessarily for consumers.
I expect that, you know, something more specialized would get this technology first.
We're talking about electricity without wires this hour on TALK OF THE NATION: SCIENCE FRIDAY from NPR News.
Talking with Andre Kurs, graduate student in physics at MIT.
Folks pretty excited in your lab?
You're getting a lot of attention?
Yes we do.

Yeah.

Too many people waiting for you.
Yeah.

Lots of females.
Is there a...

So, it's good.
It's better different...
(Soundbite of laughter)
...I'm assuming.
Maybe I shouldn't make such assumption.
So, is this what your line of work is going to be when you graduate or when you get, you know, when you get your degree.
Is this what's your PhD's going to be in?
Well, it looks like it, right now.
Yeah.
You know, I just keep working on this and we'll see where this leads.
It's hard to predict.
Do you think that there are spin offs here?
You think that there are other collaborations that possible?
I suppose so, and we're definitely getting lots of interests - lots of people interested in collaborating with us in some way.
We're still evaluating those and - I mean, we're still sort of taking a step back and breathing a little and calming down before we...
Advance.
...think about how to proceed.
Are there any energy efficiencies here?
And will - can you argue on, you know, the energy efficiency side that this is a good product, good tact here?

Well, I did a computation that, you know, showed that if we - if the system - if you were (unintelligible) on a laptop and the system were only 50 percent efficient, which is a very conservative estimate, we can get, you know, above that, then that would add about, you know, 10 additional - $10 to my electricity bill each year.
And if I were running my laptop on wireless power all year long - and I was comparing that to batteries.
I mean, I use my battery - I don't use it all the time, but I do use it quite a lot.
Right.
And I find that I need to change the battery every couple of years, and it costs me $100 every time I need to get a new one, and it's annoying.
Yeah.
And...
And...
Wasteful, and it's got all that mercury in it.
